awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
awd_abstract_narration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Andrew John MacDonald

Proposal Number: 1611767

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology.  The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Andrew J. MacDonald is "Land use change and deforestation: A cause and consequence of vector-borne disease risk in the Amazon Basin." The host institution for this fellowship is Stanford University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Erin Mordecai.  

The goal of this project is to understand the bi-directional relationship between vector-borne disease and land use change, using malaria and deforestation in the Amazon as a model system. Improved understanding of these relationships is critically important to conservation, economic development and human health. Land use change is one of the most pressing environmental issues facing society. As natural lands are cleared by humans, species reliant on the cleared habitat are lost while other species replace them. There is substantial evidence that arthropod vectors - such as mosquitoes and ticks - and the pathogens they transmit, often benefit from land use change. Yet, studies attempting to link land use change directly to human disease have yielded ambiguous results, often drawing contradictory conclusions. One important source of this ambiguity may be the existence of bi-directional feedbacks between land use change and disease that, if overlooked, can result in unreliable and misleading results. The Fellow is using robust statistical techniques widely applied in empirical economics, and high-resolution environmental and epidemiological data, to develop an understanding of the relationships between land use change and malaria. In so doing, he is helping to develop a general framework to address feedbacks between land use change and infectious disease, thereby contributing greatly to the burgeoning field of disease ecology.

The Fellow is receiving training in advanced statistical and computational modeling, incorporating techniques from econometrics and epidemiology. In addition, the Fellow's research results are being used to develop interactive educational tools and curricula in collaboration with high school teachers from underserved communities in the San Francisco Bay Area. These teachers are working to implement innovative teaching tools and strategies in their own classrooms to engage underrepresented students in STEM fields, using the Fellow's project results. The Fellow is also mentoring several high school and middle school students through programs aimed at engaging low income and first generation students in science. Finally, the Fellow is using the research results to inform conservation policy in Brazil to reduce malaria burden.

por.por_cntn:
Conversion of natural lands for human use and intensification of management of human-dominated landscapes has fundamentally altered global climate as well as ecosystem service provision (e.g., food production, freshwater, clean air). Nowhere is land use change more dramatic, with both local and global consequences, than in the planet’s remaining tropical rainforests. The largest remaining tropical forest on earth, the Amazon of South America, is experiencing rapid deforestation for development and resource extraction, the consequences of which are predicted to be calamitous for life on earth as we know it.

 

For example, land use and land cover change can influence the distribution and abundance, even local extinction, of plant and animal species that depend on particular habitats and microclimates, and may favor some species to the detriment of others. In the Amazon, there is evidence that deforestation creates breeding habitat for the mosquito vector of human malaria, as well as influences mosquito traits and vital rates to increase transmission potential of malaria parasites to humans. Despite these findings, evidence linking deforestation to human malaria burden has been equivocal.

 

While the ecological basis for an effect of deforestation on malaria is relatively straightforward (i.e., changes in microclimate, breeding habitat and human – vector contact rates), it is possible that malaria burden may feedback to influence rates of deforestation. Malaria can be a debilitating disease with economic consequences through reductions in productivity, travel, trade and migration to malaria endemic regions. Reduced economic activity could also translate into reduced forest clearing for human settlement, agriculture or resource extraction. If elevated malaria burden does indeed reduce forest clearing, this feedback could muddle the relationship between deforestation and human malaria incidence, leading to the equivocal scientific evidence.

 

Employing novel statistical approaches in the biological sciences, coupled with a remarkable dataset compiled by the fellow that included high resolution remotely sensed environmental and deforestation data, human disease incidence and socio-demographics, this fellowship research endeavored to resolve the effect of deforestation on human malaria in the Amazon. Using approaches from the social and behavioral sciences to disentangle causal relationships in the presence of such feedbacks, the fellow found robust evidence that deforestation increases malaria incidence, and that elevated malaria burden leads to reduced deforestation. Further, the effect was found to be larger in the interior, more heavily forested, region of the Amazon basin, than on the edge of the Amazon where much forest has already been cleared and human settlements consolidated, and that the effect of deforestation on malaria is underestimated by a factor of three when not controlling for the significant feedback from malaria back to deforestation.

 

These novel results help to clarify the equivocal understanding of the effect of a globally important process of land use change (deforestation), in the largest remaining rainforest on earth, on a globally important infectious disease that has plagued humanity for millennia. These results have clear policy relevance, and imply a possible win-win solution for conservation and human health. Ongoing work is further attempting to resolve what effect land use policy, forest conservation and future land use change in the region might have on malaria transmission as the physical and policy landscapes of the Amazon basin evolve.

 

During the fellowship period, the fellow provided research and mentorship opportunities for numerous underrepresented masters, undergraduate and high school students in geospatial data analysis and disease ecology. Many of these students are continuing in STEM fields in higher education (e.g., as PhD students in biology, undergraduates in biomedical engineering), in science and cultural outreach programs (e.g., Fulbright Scholars Program in Colombia), as well as continuing to be collaborators on vector-borne disease ecology research. Professional development and short course materials are also in development for undergraduate and high school students as part of the ongoing outreach efforts of this project (e.g., how to apply to grad school, what can you do with a PhD in disease ecology, etc., as well as materials for a course on the importance of arthropods in society – as vectors of disease, crop pests, pollinators, natural enemies, foodwebs/trophic dynamics – that will be offered in the future as part of a series for underrepresented high school students in STEM). Integration of these materials with programs like the McNair Scholars Program for underrepresented students will have a lasting impact on human resource development. All of these research and teaching opportunities have and will continue to improve attitudes of underrepresented students toward STEM fields, particularly biology and the ecology of infectious disease, and will increase exposure to and interest in these important topics in underserved and underrepresented communities. Further, collaborations forged with researchers and NGO’s on the ground working on issues of health and the environment in Peru and Borneo as part of this fellowship tenure will continue to foster knowledge transfer and human resource development in the developing world.
